title: 111_s3572
content: The Act is titled the "United States Marshals Service 225th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act". The United States Marshals Service, established in 1789 under the Judiciary Act, was the first law enforcement agency in America. George Washington appointed the first 13 Marshals shortly after signing the Act into law. The United States Marshals Service has had significant historical importance in the country, serving as a civil authority for all branches of government. Robert Forsyth, one of the original 13 Marshals, was the first to be killed in the line of duty in 1794. The United States Marshals Service Commemorative Coin will be the first to honor the agency. The United States Marshals Service established a 225th Anniversary Committee in 2008 to ensure a national observance of their anniversary in 2014. A commemorative coin will bring attention to the agency's legacy, and the United States should mint and issue these coins to pay tribute to the oldest law enforcement agency in the country. The sale of commemorative coins will fund national monuments, museums, and charitable organizations, including the United States Marshals Service National Museum, the National Law Enforcement Museum and Memorial, and the Center for Missing and Exploited Children. The commemorative coins will fund various national organizations and museums, including the United States Marshals Service National Museum, the National Law Enforcement Museum and Memorial, and the Center for Missing and Exploited Children. SEC. 3 outlines the coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service. The $5 gold coins will weigh 33.931 grams and contain 1 troy ounce of fine gold, while the $1 silver coins will weigh 26.73 grams and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent alloy. These coins will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act for the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service will be considered numismatic items and not subject to mintage level coordination as per section 5112(m)(2)(A) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the achievements of the United States Marshals Service, with inscriptions including the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The obverse of the $5 gold coins will feature specific imagery. The $5 coins issued under this Act will feature the Marshals Services Star on the obverse and a design honoring fallen US Marshals on the reverse. The edge of the coins may bear the motto "Justice, Integrity." The $1 silver coins issued under this Act will have the Marshals Services Star on the obverse and may bear the motto "Justice, Integrity, Service" on the edge. The designs of coins issued under this Act will be realistic and historically accurate, reminiscent of the artwork from the "Golden Age of Coinage" in the United States. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Director of the United States Marshals Service and the Historian. The design of coins issued under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Director and Historian of the United States Marshals Service, and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee and the United States Marshals Service 225th Anniversary Committee. The Secretary will select the design of coins issued under this Act in consultation with relevant committees. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in proof and uncirculated quality at a single United States Mint facility. The Secretary may start issuing coins on September 24, 2014, the 225th anniversary of the United States Marshals Service, with a limited number issued earlier for display. Minting authority for these coins ends on December 31, 2015. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in section 7(a), and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount, and arrangements will be made for United States Marshals Service employees. The United States Marshals Service employees, verified by the Director, will have a defined period to place prepaid orders at a reasonable discount for $5 gold and $1 silver coins. The Secretary will offer a presentation case displaying the coins with the current badge of the United States Marshals Service. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a surcharge: $35 per $5 gold coin and $10 per $1 silver coin. Surcharges received will be distributed, with the first $5,000,000 going to the United States Marshals Service National Museum in Fort Smith, Arkansas, for preservation and display. The Act includes donations of $1,000,000 each to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund, and the Federal Law Enforcement Officers Association. Additionally, $500,000 is allocated to the William "Bill" Degan Scholarship Fund and the Robert D. May Scholarship Fund for scholarships for families of law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty. The Act allocates $500,000 each to the Community Oriented Policing Service and the United States Marshals Service Association. All organizations, associations, and funds under this Act are subject to audit requirements. No surcharge may be included for issuing commemorative coins if it exceeds the annual limit. The Secretary may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual commemorative coin issuance limit under title 31, United States Code. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell bronze duplicates of the $5 gold coins at a price determined to be appropriate.
